case_vignette:
A 13-year-old girl presents with a cystic lesion that has been on her forearm for several years. Concerned about the lesion, she reports that it may have grown slightly larger in the past year and it is intermittently painful. More recently, a second similar lesion has appeared in close proximity. She denies any other suspicious lesions elsewhere on her skin. Her family history is negative for skin cancer, and she reports no other medical conditions. Physical examination reveals two well-defined 6-mm nodules that are rubbery, slightly tender, and pink on the right proximal ventral forearm. The overlying skin is intact, and there is no associated adenopathy. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms. The differential diagnosis for this patient includes pilomatricoma, keratoacanthoma, and basal cell carcinoma. The most likely diagnosis is pilomatricoma, given the patient's age, the location of the lesions, and the clinical presentation.

Their family history is negative for skin cancer, and they report no other medical conditions. Physical examination reveals two well-defined 6-mm nodules that are rubbery, slightly tender, and pink on the right proximal ventral forearm. The overlying skin is intact, and there is no associated adenopathy. The patient is otherwise healthy and has no other symptoms. The differential diagnosis for this patient includes pilomatricoma, keratoacanthoma, and basal cell carcinoma. The most likely diagnosis is pilomatricoma, given the patient's age, the location of the lesions, and the clinical presentation.

question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?

Hi! I have a cystic lesion on my forearm that has been there for several years and has grown slightly larger in the past year. It's intermittently painful, and recently, a second similar lesion has appeared close to it.
Has there been any change in the color or consistency of these lesions?
No, the lesions are still rubbery and pink, and the skin over them is intact.
Do you have a history of similar lesions elsewhere on your body or any family history of skin conditions?
No, I don't have any other suspicious lesions elsewhere on my skin and my family history is negative for skin cancer.
Do you have any other medical conditions or take any medications that might affect your skin?
No, I do not have any other medical conditions and I am not taking any medications.
Final Diagnosis: Dermatofibroma
